Situation1: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story: The snow was coming down in thick, blinding sheets as I gripped the steering wheel, my knuckles white. My passenger kept glancing at his watch, his voice tense as he reminded me, “I can’t miss this flight. Please, can you go any faster?” I knew the airport was still miles away, and the roads were slick with ice. As a taxi driver, I was expected to get him there safely and on time, but every minute lost in traffic felt like a failure. At the same time, my phone buzzed with messages from my family, already gathered at the temple for the festival. Today was the most sacred day, and I was supposed to be there, offering prayers and lighting lamps with them. My heart ached with guilt—my faith demanded my presence, my job demanded my focus. The storm outside mirrored the turmoil inside me. I could not be in two places at once, and both roles pulled at me with equal force. I stared at the swirling snow, torn between duty and devotion, not knowing which path I would choose.
